trans-unit.source: Filter Based Feature Selection
trans-unit.target: Filter Based Feature Selection

trans-unit.source: Identifies the features in a dataset with the greatest predictive power
trans-unit.target: Identifies the features in a dataset with the greatest predictive power

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="CC98F178-B2ED-44A0-8B35-8D02B266F20B" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Feature Selection Modules</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="CC98F178-B2ED-44A0-8B35-8D02B266F20B" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Feature Selection Modules</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> module to identify the subset of input columns that have the greatest predictive power.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> module to identify the subset of input columns that have the greatest predictive power.

trans-unit.source: In general, <newTerm>feature selection</newTerm> refers to the process of applying statistical tests to input values given a specified output, to determine which columns are more predictive for the output.
trans-unit.target: In general, <newTerm>feature selection</newTerm> refers to the process of applying statistical tests to input values given a specified output, to determine which columns are more predictive for the output.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> module provides multiple feature selection algorithms, which you apply based on the type of predictive task and data types.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> module provides multiple feature selection algorithms, which you apply based on the type of predictive task and data types.

trans-unit.source: The module outputs a dataset containing the specified number of best feature columns, as ranked by predictive power, but also outputs the names of the features and their scores from the selected metric.
trans-unit.target: The module outputs a dataset containing the specified number of best feature columns, as ranked by predictive power, but also outputs the names of the features and their scores from the selected metric.

trans-unit.source: Understanding Filter-Based Feature Selection
trans-unit.target: Understanding Filter-Based Feature Selection

trans-unit.source: Feature selection is the process of selecting those attributes in your dataset that are most relevant to the predictive modeling problem you are working on.
trans-unit.target: Feature selection is the process of selecting those attributes in your dataset that are most relevant to the predictive modeling problem you are working on.

trans-unit.source: By choosing the right features, you can potentially improve the accuracy and efficiency of classification.
trans-unit.target: By choosing the right features, you can potentially improve the accuracy and efficiency of classification.

trans-unit.source: Feature selection can also be used to identify unneeded, irrelevant and redundant attributes in the dataset.
trans-unit.target: Feature selection can also be used to identify unneeded, irrelevant and redundant attributes in the dataset.

trans-unit.source: By applying statistical measures, you can determine which columns do not contribute to the accuracy of the predictive model (or might in fact decrease the accuracy of the model) and remove them before training a model
trans-unit.target: By applying statistical measures, you can determine which columns do not contribute to the accuracy of the predictive model (or might in fact decrease the accuracy of the model) and remove them before training a model

trans-unit.source: <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> uses different statistical tests to determine the subset of features with the highest predictive power.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> uses different statistical tests to determine the subset of features with the highest predictive power.

trans-unit.source: You choose a statistical measure to apply, and the module calculates a score for each column that you have used as a feature.
trans-unit.target: You choose a statistical measure to apply, and the module calculates a score for each column that you have used as a feature.

trans-unit.source: The features are then ranked by the score and the feature columns with the best scores are used in building the model, while others are kept in the dataset but not used for analysis.
trans-unit.target: The features are then ranked by the score and the feature columns with the best scores are used in building the model, while others are kept in the dataset but not used for analysis.

trans-unit.source: The choice of feature selection scoring method to use depends in part on the type of data you have.
trans-unit.target: The choice of feature selection scoring method to use depends in part on the type of data you have.

trans-unit.source: For example, some methods require numeric data; others can work with data that represents ranking.
trans-unit.target: For example, some methods require numeric data; others can work with data that represents ranking.

trans-unit.source: If you apply a scoring method to a column that has a data type not supported by the method, a zero score is assigned.
trans-unit.target: If you apply a scoring method to a column that has a data type not supported by the method, a zero score is assigned.

trans-unit.source: Check the requirements in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#Notes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section before choosing a method.
trans-unit.target: Check the requirements in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#Notes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section before choosing a method.

trans-unit.source: If you need to define a custom feature selection method, you can use the <link xlink:href="30806023-392b-42e0-94d6-6b775a6e0fd5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Execute R Script</link> module.
trans-unit.target: If you need to define a custom feature selection method, you can use the <link xlink:href="30806023-392b-42e0-94d6-6b775a6e0fd5" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Execute R Script</link> module.

trans-unit.source: How to Use Feature Selection
trans-unit.target: How to Use Feature Selection

trans-unit.source: To use count-based feature selection
trans-unit.target: To use count-based feature selection

trans-unit.source: Connect an input dataset that contains at least two columns that are candidates for use as features.
trans-unit.target: Connect an input dataset that contains at least two columns that are candidates for use as features.

trans-unit.source: Select <ui>Count Based</ui> from the list of statistical methods in the <ui>Feature scoring method</ui> dropdown list.
trans-unit.target: Select <ui>Count Based</ui> from the list of statistical methods in the <ui>Feature scoring method</ui> dropdown list.

trans-unit.source: Specify the minimum number of non-zero elements that must be present in each column, in order for a count score to be generated.
trans-unit.target: Specify the minimum number of non-zero elements that must be present in each column, in order for a count score to be generated.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you know that a column has a lot of zero (0) values that probably represent missing values, you can increase the value for this requirement to exclude the column.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you know that a column has a lot of zero (0) values that probably represent missing values, you can increase the value for this requirement to exclude the column.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, all columns are counted and scored, even the label column.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, all columns are counted and scored, even the label column.

trans-unit.source: To use all other feature selection methods
trans-unit.target: To use all other feature selection methods

trans-unit.source: Connect an input dataset that contains at least two columns that are candidates for use as features.
trans-unit.target: Connect an input dataset that contains at least two columns that are candidates for use as features.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that a column should be scored as a feature, use the <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> module to set the <legacyBold>IsFeature</legacyBold> attribute.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that a column should be scored as a feature, use the <link xlink:href="370b6676-c11c-486f-bf73-35349f842a66" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Metadata Editor</link> module to set the <legacyBold>IsFeature</legacyBold> attribute.

trans-unit.source: If your dataset contains a mix of text and numeric columns, you might wish to use the <link xlink:href="1ec722fa-b623-4e26-a44e-a50c6d726223" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Project Columns</link> module to separate them, so that you can take advantage of feature selection methods that require numeric columns.
trans-unit.target: If your dataset contains a mix of text and numeric columns, you might wish to use the <link xlink:href="1ec722fa-b623-4e26-a44e-a50c6d726223" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Project Columns</link> module to separate them, so that you can take advantage of feature selection methods that require numeric columns.

trans-unit.source: Select a metric from the list of statistical methods in the <ui>Feature scoring method</ui> dropdown list.
trans-unit.target: Select a metric from the list of statistical methods in the <ui>Feature scoring method</ui> dropdown list.

trans-unit.source: If you change the metric, all other selections will be reset.
trans-unit.target: If you change the metric, all other selections will be reset.

trans-unit.source: Select the column that contains the label.
trans-unit.target: Select the column that contains the label.

trans-unit.source: A label column is required for all methods, except count-based feature selection.
trans-unit.target: A label column is required for all methods, except count-based feature selection.

trans-unit.source: The following metrics require that the label values be numeric:
trans-unit.target: The following metrics require that the label values be numeric:

trans-unit.source: Kendall Correlation
trans-unit.target: Kendall Correlation

trans-unit.source: Pearson Correlation
trans-unit.target: Pearson Correlation

trans-unit.source: Spearman Correlation
trans-unit.target: Spearman Correlation

trans-unit.source: Specify how many features you want returned, of the available feature columns.
trans-unit.target: Specify how many features you want returned, of the available feature columns.

trans-unit.source: All metrics (excluding count-based feature selection) order the returned feature columns in descending order of their feature scores.
trans-unit.target: All metrics (excluding count-based feature selection) order the returned feature columns in descending order of their feature scores.

trans-unit.source: The module generates these outputs:
trans-unit.target: The module generates these outputs:

trans-unit.source: The first output is a dataset containing the columns that were identified as being the best features, meaning they had the highest predictive scores using the selected metric.
trans-unit.target: The first output is a dataset containing the columns that were identified as being the best features, meaning they had the highest predictive scores using the selected metric.

trans-unit.source: This dataset also includes the selected target column, in the leftmost column of the output table.
trans-unit.target: This dataset also includes the selected target column, in the leftmost column of the output table.

trans-unit.source: This way you can see in the results which target the input columns were correlated with.
trans-unit.target: This way you can see in the results which target the input columns were correlated with.

trans-unit.source: The columns are ordered by descending feature importance score.
trans-unit.target: The columns are ordered by descending feature importance score.

trans-unit.source: The second output is a short table containing just the scores for those columns, given the selected metric and parameters.
trans-unit.target: The second output is a short table containing just the scores for those columns, given the selected metric and parameters.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Count Based</ui> feature selection generates a count score for every column in the dataset, and returns the columns in their original order.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Count Based</ui> feature selection generates a count score for every column in the dataset, and returns the columns in their original order.

trans-unit.source: Feature Selection Options
trans-unit.target: Feature Selection Options

trans-unit.source: Feature scoring method
trans-unit.target: Feature scoring method

trans-unit.source: Choose a statistical method to use in calculating scores.
trans-unit.target: Choose a statistical method to use in calculating scores.

trans-unit.source: For all methods except count-based feature selection, scores are generated for a pair of columns, where one column contains the label and the other column contains feature values.
trans-unit.target: For all methods except count-based feature selection, scores are generated for a pair of columns, where one column contains the label and the other column contains feature values.

trans-unit.source: Pearson Correlation
trans-unit.target: Pearson Correlation

trans-unit.source: Requires numeric label; otherwise returns an error.
trans-unit.target: Requires numeric label; otherwise returns an error.

trans-unit.source: Mutual Information
trans-unit.target: Mutual Information

trans-unit.source: Labels and features can be text or numeric.
trans-unit.target: Labels and features can be text or numeric.

trans-unit.source: Kendall Correlation
trans-unit.target: Kendall Correlation

trans-unit.source: Requires numeric label; otherwise returns an error.
trans-unit.target: Requires numeric label; otherwise returns an error.

trans-unit.source: Spearman Correlation
trans-unit.target: Spearman Correlation

trans-unit.source: Requires numeric label; otherwise returns an error.
trans-unit.target: Requires numeric label; otherwise returns an error.

trans-unit.source: Chi Squared
trans-unit.target: Chi Squared

trans-unit.source: Accepts a text column for labels, but generates a score of 0 for all non numeric features.
trans-unit.target: Accepts a text column for labels, but generates a score of 0 for all non numeric features.

trans-unit.source: Fisher Score
trans-unit.target: Fisher Score

trans-unit.source: Accepts a text column for labels, but generates a score of 0 for all non numeric features.
trans-unit.target: Accepts a text column for labels, but generates a score of 0 for all non numeric features.

trans-unit.source: Count Based
trans-unit.target: Count Based

trans-unit.source: For detailed information about these scores, see the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Details" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information about these scores, see the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Details" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section.

trans-unit.source: Operate on feature columns only
trans-unit.target: Operate on feature columns only

trans-unit.source: Select this option to generate a score only for those columns that have been previously marked as features.
trans-unit.target: Select this option to generate a score only for those columns that have been previously marked as features.

trans-unit.source: If you deselect this option, the module will create a score for any column that has a data type that is valid for the specified metric.
trans-unit.target: If you deselect this option, the module will create a score for any column that has a data type that is valid for the specified metric.

trans-unit.source: A feature selection score cannot be generated for any column that is designated as a <embeddedLabel>label</embeddedLabel> or as a <embeddedLabel>score</embeddedLabel> column.
trans-unit.target: A feature selection score cannot be generated for any column that is designated as a <embeddedLabel>label</embeddedLabel> or as a <embeddedLabel>score</embeddedLabel> column.

trans-unit.source: Target column
trans-unit.target: Target column

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Launch column selector</ui> to choose the target column either by name or by its index (indexes are one-based).
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Launch column selector</ui> to choose the target column either by name or by its index (indexes are one-based).

trans-unit.source: The module returns a design-time error if you choose no label column or too many columns.
trans-unit.target: The module returns a design-time error if you choose no label column or too many columns.

trans-unit.source: However, if you choose a column with the wrong data type, or a non label column, the module will return an error only when the experiment is run.
trans-unit.target: However, if you choose a column with the wrong data type, or a non label column, the module will return an error only when the experiment is run.

trans-unit.source: Number of desired features
trans-unit.target: Number of desired features

trans-unit.source: For almost all methods, you can specify the number of best features that you want returned.
trans-unit.target: For almost all methods, you can specify the number of best features that you want returned.

trans-unit.source: Each method scores all input columns, ranks the features by descending score, and returns only the top features.
trans-unit.target: Each method scores all input columns, ranks the features by descending score, and returns only the top features.

trans-unit.source: The exception is count-based feature selection, which by default processes all columns passed as inputs.
trans-unit.target: The exception is count-based feature selection, which by default processes all columns passed as inputs.

trans-unit.source: The minimum number of features you can specify is 1, but we recommend that you increase this value.
trans-unit.target: The minimum number of features you can specify is 1, but we recommend that you increase this value.

trans-unit.source: If the specified number of desired features is greater than the number of columns in the dataset, then all features are returned.
trans-unit.target: If the specified number of desired features is greater than the number of columns in the dataset, then all features are returned.

trans-unit.source: Examples
trans-unit.target: Examples

trans-unit.source: You can see examples of how this module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: You can see examples of how this module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: In the third step of the <externalLink><linkText>Text Classification </linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/cf65bf129fee4190b6f48a53e599a755</linkUri></externalLink> sample, <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> is used to identify the 15 best features.
trans-unit.target: In the third step of the <externalLink><linkText>Text Classification </linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/cf65bf129fee4190b6f48a53e599a755</linkUri></externalLink> sample, <ui>Filter-Based Feature Selection</ui> is used to identify the 15 best features.

trans-unit.source: Feature hashing is used to convert the text documents to numeric vectors that can be used to calculate Pearson’s correlation.
trans-unit.target: Feature hashing is used to convert the text documents to numeric vectors that can be used to calculate Pearson’s correlation.

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: If you attempt to use a scoring method with a column of a data type not supported by the method, either the module will raise an error, or a zero score will be assigned to the column.
trans-unit.target: If you attempt to use a scoring method with a column of a data type not supported by the method, either the module will raise an error, or a zero score will be assigned to the column.

trans-unit.source: If a column contains logical (true/false) values, they are processed as True = 1 and False = 0.
trans-unit.target: If a column contains logical (true/false) values, they are processed as True = 1 and False = 0.

trans-unit.source: A column cannot be a feature if it has been designated as a <embeddedLabel>Label</embeddedLabel> or a <embeddedLabel>Score</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: A column cannot be a feature if it has been designated as a <embeddedLabel>Label</embeddedLabel> or a <embeddedLabel>Score</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Missing Values
trans-unit.target: Missing Values

trans-unit.source: You cannot specify as a target (label) column any column that has all missing values.
trans-unit.target: You cannot specify as a target (label) column any column that has all missing values.

trans-unit.source: If a column contains missing values, they are ignored when computing the score for the column.
trans-unit.target: If a column contains missing values, they are ignored when computing the score for the column.

trans-unit.source: If a column designated as a feature column has all missing values, a zero score is assigned.
trans-unit.target: If a column designated as a feature column has all missing values, a zero score is assigned.

trans-unit.source: Requirements
trans-unit.target: Requirements

trans-unit.source: The following scoring methods accept only numeric and logical data columns:
trans-unit.target: The following scoring methods accept only numeric and logical data columns:

trans-unit.source: Pearson Correlation
trans-unit.target: Pearson Correlation

trans-unit.source: Kendall Correlation
trans-unit.target: Kendall Correlation

trans-unit.source: Spearman Correlation
trans-unit.target: Spearman Correlation

trans-unit.source: Fisher Score.
trans-unit.target: Fisher Score.

trans-unit.source: However, the restriction does not apply to the target column.
trans-unit.target: However, the restriction does not apply to the target column.

trans-unit.source: Details of the Feature Selection Methods
trans-unit.target: Details of the Feature Selection Methods

trans-unit.source: <ui>Filter -Based Feature Selection</ui> provides a selection of widely used statistical tests for determining the subset of input columns that have the greatest predictive power.
trans-unit.target: <ui>Filter -Based Feature Selection</ui> provides a selection of widely used statistical tests for determining the subset of input columns that have the greatest predictive power.

trans-unit.source: Pearson Correlation
trans-unit.target: Pearson Correlation

trans-unit.source: Pearson’s correlation statistics or Pearson’s correlation coefficient is also known in statistical models as the <languageKeyword>r</languageKeyword> value.
trans-unit.target: Pearson’s correlation statistics or Pearson’s correlation coefficient is also known in statistical models as the <languageKeyword>r</languageKeyword> value.

trans-unit.source: For any two variables, it returns a value that indicates the strength of the correlation.
trans-unit.target: For any two variables, it returns a value that indicates the strength of the correlation.

trans-unit.source: Pearson's correlation coefficient is computed by taking the covariance of two variables and dividing by the product of their standard deviations.
trans-unit.target: Pearson's correlation coefficient is computed by taking the covariance of two variables and dividing by the product of their standard deviations.

trans-unit.source: The coefficient is not affected by changes of scale in the two variables.
trans-unit.target: The coefficient is not affected by changes of scale in the two variables.

trans-unit.source: Mutual Information
trans-unit.target: Mutual Information

trans-unit.source: The Mutual Information Score method measures the contribution of a variable towards reducing uncertainty about the value of another variable — in this case, the label.
trans-unit.target: The Mutual Information Score method measures the contribution of a variable towards reducing uncertainty about the value of another variable — in this case, the label.

trans-unit.source: Many variations of the mutual information score have been devised to suit different distributions.
trans-unit.target: Many variations of the mutual information score have been devised to suit different distributions.

trans-unit.source: The mutual information score is particularly useful in feature selection because it maximizes the mutual information between the joint distribution and target variables in datasets with many dimensions.
trans-unit.target: The mutual information score is particularly useful in feature selection because it maximizes the mutual information between the joint distribution and target variables in datasets with many dimensions.

trans-unit.source: Kendall Correlation
trans-unit.target: Kendall Correlation

trans-unit.source: Kendall's rank correlation is one of several statistics that measure the relationship between rankings of different ordinal variables or different rankings of the same variable.
trans-unit.target: Kendall's rank correlation is one of several statistics that measure the relationship between rankings of different ordinal variables or different rankings of the same variable.

trans-unit.source: In other words, it measures the similarity of orderings when ranked by the quantities.
trans-unit.target: In other words, it measures the similarity of orderings when ranked by the quantities.

trans-unit.source: Both this coefficient and Spearman’s correlation coefficient are designed for use with non-parametric and non-normally distributed data.
trans-unit.target: Both this coefficient and Spearman’s correlation coefficient are designed for use with non-parametric and non-normally distributed data.

trans-unit.source: Spearman Correlation
trans-unit.target: Spearman Correlation

trans-unit.source: Spearman's coefficient is a nonparametric measure of statistical dependence between two variables, and is sometimes denoted by the Greek letter rho.
trans-unit.target: Spearman's coefficient is a nonparametric measure of statistical dependence between two variables, and is sometimes denoted by the Greek letter rho.

trans-unit.source: The Spearman’s coefficient expresses the degree to which two variables are monotonically related.
trans-unit.target: The Spearman’s coefficient expresses the degree to which two variables are monotonically related.

trans-unit.source: It is also called Spearman rank correlation, because it can be used with ordinal variables.
trans-unit.target: It is also called Spearman rank correlation, because it can be used with ordinal variables.

trans-unit.source: Chi-Squared
trans-unit.target: Chi-Squared

trans-unit.source: The two-way chi-squared test is a statistical method that measures how close expected values are to actual results.
trans-unit.target: The two-way chi-squared test is a statistical method that measures how close expected values are to actual results.

trans-unit.source: The method assumes that variables are random and drawn from an adequate sample of independent variables.
trans-unit.target: The method assumes that variables are random and drawn from an adequate sample of independent variables.

trans-unit.source: The resulting chi-squared statistic indicates how far results are from the expected (random) result.
trans-unit.target: The resulting chi-squared statistic indicates how far results are from the expected (random) result.

trans-unit.source: Fisher Score
trans-unit.target: Fisher Score

trans-unit.source: The Fisher score (also called the Fisher method, or Fisher combined probability score) is sometimes termed the information score, because it represents the amount of information that one variable provides about some unknown parameter on which it depends.
trans-unit.target: The Fisher score (also called the Fisher method, or Fisher combined probability score) is sometimes termed the information score, because it represents the amount of information that one variable provides about some unknown parameter on which it depends.

trans-unit.source: The score is computed by measuring the variance between the expected value of the information and the observed value.
trans-unit.target: The score is computed by measuring the variance between the expected value of the information and the observed value.

trans-unit.source: When variance is minimized, information is maximized.
trans-unit.target: When variance is minimized, information is maximized.

trans-unit.source: Since the expectation of the score is zero, the Fisher information is also the variance of the score.
trans-unit.target: Since the expectation of the score is zero, the Fisher information is also the variance of the score.

trans-unit.source: Count-Based
trans-unit.target: Count-Based

trans-unit.source: Count-based feature selection is a simple yet relatively powerful way of finding information about predictors.
trans-unit.target: Count-based feature selection is a simple yet relatively powerful way of finding information about predictors.

trans-unit.source: It is a non-supervised method of feature selection, meaning you don't need a label column.
trans-unit.target: It is a non-supervised method of feature selection, meaning you don't need a label column.

trans-unit.source: This method counts the frequencies of all values and then assigns a score to the column based on frequency count.
trans-unit.target: This method counts the frequencies of all values and then assigns a score to the column based on frequency count.

trans-unit.source: It can be used to find the weight of information in a particular feature and reduce the dimensionality of the data without losing information.
trans-unit.target: It can be used to find the weight of information in a particular feature and reduce the dimensionality of the data without losing information.

trans-unit.source: Features

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more specified columns of data set couldn't be found.

trans-unit.source: Exception occurs if one or more of inputs are null or empty.
